case_name: Messrs. Hind State Private Ltd. v. Respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1972 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from Judgment Order dated 31st May 1971 of Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 2519 of 1970.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment Order dated the 31st May, 1971 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 2519 of 1970.

facts.text: Suit for eviction filed on May 19 1953 by Messrs Hind State Private Ltd predecessors-in-title of appellants against respondent on ground of non-payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: Long, long back on May 19, 1953 Messrs. Hind State Private Ltd., the predecessors-in-title of the appellants, filed against the respondent a suit for eviction on the ground of number-payment of rent.

facts.text: On November 24 1958 learned Second Munsif Alipore passed decree for possession in favour of plaintiffs holding respondent not entitled to protection of West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act 1950 due to defaults in payment of rent.

anchor.surface_text: On November 24, 1958 the learned Second Munsif, Alipore, passed a decree for possession in favour of the plaintiffs holding that by reason of defaults in the payment of rent, the respondent was number entitled to the protection of the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950.

facts.text: Decree confirmed in appeal by learned Subordinate Judge 4th Court Alipore on April 12 1967.

anchor.surface_text: That decree was companyfirmed in appeal by the learned Subordinate Judge, 4th Court, Alipore, on April 12, 1967.

facts.text: During pendency of appeal appellants purchased right title and interest of plaintiffs in suit premises and obtained assignment of decretal rights brought on record of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the appeal, the appellants had purchased the right, title and interest of the plantiffs in the suit premises and they had also obtained an assignment of the decretal rights in their favour. They were therefore brought on the record of the appeal in place of the original plantiffs.

facts.text: Respondent filed Second Appeal No 1255 of 1967 against decree of 1st appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed Second Appeal No. 1255 of 1967 against the decree of the 1st appellate companyrt

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court of Calcutta dismissed Second Appeal after contested hearing on January 8 1969.

anchor.surface_text: and that appeal, after a companytested hearing, was dismissed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Calcutta on January 8, 1969.

facts.text: High Court granted respondent time to vacate suit premises till end of January 1970 on giving written undertaking to hand over possession to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: While dismissing the appeal, the High Court granted to the respondent time to vacate the suit premises till the end of January, 1970 on the respondent giving a written undertaking to the companyrt that he will hand over quiet and peaceful possession of the premises to the appellants on the expiry of the aforesaid period.

facts.text: Respondent made application under section 17D on January 12 1970 to set aside decree for possession.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1970 which was a few days before he had under taken to vacate the Premises, the respondent made an application under section 17 D Asking that the decree for possession passed Against him be set aside.

facts.text: Learned Munsif Second Court Alipore dismissed application under section 17D on July 15 1970 holding decree of trial court merged in High Court decree.

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment dated July 15, 1970 the learned Munsif, Second Court, Alipore, dismissed that application on the ground that the decree for possession passed by the trial companyrt on November 24, 1958, had merged in the decree passed by the High Court on January 8, 1969, that in truth and in substance the operative decree was the one passed by the High Court and as that decree was, passed after August 26, 1967

facts.text: Calcutta High Court single Judge allowed revision application on May 31 1971 granted section 17D application and directed dismissal of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a revision application in the High Court of Calcutta against the judgment of the learned Munsif. By a judgment dated May 31, 1971 a learned single Judge of the High Court allowed the revision application, granted the application filed by the respondent under section 17 D and directed the dismissal of the suit.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellants to appeal from High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has granted to the appellants special leave to appeal, from the judgment of the High Court.

facts.text: Decree dated November 24 1958 passed by trial court in suit under 1950 Act by reason only of clause (i) proviso to sub-section (1) of section 12 on ground of default in payment of rent not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: it is number in dispute that the decree dated November 24, 1958 for possession of the suit premises was passed by the trial companyrt in a suit filed by the appellants predecessors-in- interest under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950, by reason only of clause  1  of the proviso to sub-section  1  of section 12 of that Act, that is to say, on the ground that the respondent had defaulted in the payment of rent.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds decree of trial court dated November 24 1958 merged in decree of High Court dated January 8 1969.

anchor.surface_text: We, are accordingly of the opinion that the decree of the trial companyrt dated November 24, 1958 merged in the decree of the High Court dated January 8, 1969.

facts.text: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act 1950 repealed by section 40 of West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act XII of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950 was repealed by section 40 of the West Bengal. Premises Tenancy Act, XII of 1956.

facts.text: Proclamation of emergency issued by President of India on February 20 1968.

anchor.surface_text: During the Proclamation, of emergency issued by the President of India on February 20, 1968, Act XII of 1956 was amended by the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Amendment  Act, Presidents Act 4 of 1968

facts.text: Presidents Act 4 of 1968 given retrospective effect from August 26 1967.

anchor.surface_text: which was given retrospective effect from August 26, 1967.

facts.text: West Bengal Premises Tenancy Second Amendment Act 1969 came into force on November 14 1969 introducing section 17D.

anchor.surface_text: The Act of 1956  by the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Second Amendment  Act, 1969  The Act of 1969  which came into force on November 14, 1969.

facts.text: High Court decree passed after commencement of West Bengal Premises Tenancy Amendment Act 1968 on August 26 1967 so section 17D not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: Since the decree. of the High Court was passed after the companymencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Amendment  Act 1968, that is to say after August 26, 1967, section 17D of the Act of 1956 can have number application

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal sets aside High Court judgment of May 31 1971 restores Munsif judgment of July 15 1970.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court dated May 31, 1971 and restore that of the Munsif, Second Court, Alipore dated July 15, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned in this appeal with the provisions of section 17 D which was introduced in the Act of 1956 by the Act of 1969. That section, in so far as material, reads thus 17 D. Power of Court to set aside, decrees passed on account of default in the payment of rent. Where before the companymencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Amendment  Act, 1968, a decree for the recovery of possession of any premises was passed-  a   b  in a suit under the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950, by reason only of clause  i  of the proviso to subsection.,  1  of section 12 of that Act, but the possession of such premises had number been recovered from the tenant by the execution of the decree, the tenant may within a period of sixty days from the date of companymencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Second Amendment  Act, 1969, make an application to the Court which passed the decree to set aside the decree.

concepts.interpretation: Applies only to decrees passed before commencement of 1968 Amendment Act (Aug 26, 1967); since trial court decree merged in High Court decree passed after that date, section 17D has no application.

Hind State Private Ltd., the predecessors-in-title of the appellants, filed against the respondent a suit for eviction on the ground of number-payment of rent.

issues.text: whether by reason of section 17 D of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956 the decree for eviction is incapable of execution

anchor.surface_text: 2  whether by reason of section 17 D of the, West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956 the decree for eviction is incapable of execution. Long, long back on May 19, 1953 Messrs. Hind State Private Ltd., the predecessors-in-title of the appellants, filed against the respondent a suit for eviction on the ground of number-payment of rent. On November 24, 1958 the learned Second Munsif, Alipore, passed a decree for possession in favour of the plaintiffs holding that by reason of defaults in the payment of rent, the respondent was number entitled to the protection of the West Bengal Premises Rent Control  Temporary Provisions  Act, 1950.

issues.text: whether the decree for the recovery of possession can be said to have been passed against the respondent before the commencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Amendment Act, 1968, that is, before August 26, 1967

anchor.surface_text: plied with. The question which arises for companysideration is whether the decree for the recovery of possession can be said to have been passed against the respondent before the companymencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Amendment  Act, 1968, that is to say, before August 26, 1967. If it was passed before that date, the respondent would be entitled to claim the benefit of section 17 D, in which event the decree passed in the suit has to be set aside and there would be then numberout- standing decree to execute. It is indisputable that a decree for possession was in fact passed in favour of the appellants predecessors-in-interest by the trial companyrt on November 24, 1958 which was before the companymencement of the Act of 1968.

issues.text: whether the decree passed by the trial court can be deemed to have merged in the decree passed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: principle of merger but a few preliminary observations will facilitate a better understanding of those decisions. The juristic justification of the doctrine of merger may be sought in the principle that there cannot be, at one and the same time. more than one operative order governing the same subject-matter. Therefore the judgment of an inferior companyrt, if subjected to an examination by the superior companyrt, ceases to have existence in the eye of law and is treated as being superseded by the judgment of the superior companyrt. In other words, the judgment of the inferior companyrt loses its identity by its merger with the judgment of the superior companyrt. Stated in this form the principle may appear to be unexceptionable but the problem has many facets.

arguments.claim: Decree of trial court dated November 24, 1958 merged in decree of High Court dated January 8, 1969; operative decree is High Court decree passed after August 26, 1967; section 17D application not maintainable

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment dated July 15, 1970 the learned Munsif, Second Court, Alipore, dismissed that application on the ground that the decree for possession passed by the trial court on November 24, 1958, had merged in the decree passed by the High Court on January 8, 1969, that in truth and in substance the operative decree was the one passed by the High Court and as that decree was, passed after August 26, 1967

arguments.claim: In case where appellate court dismisses the appeal, principle of merger has no application; effective decree is trial court decree dated November 24, 1958 passed before commencement of Presidents Act 4 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a revision application in the High Court of Calcutta against the judgment of the learned Munsif. By a judgment dated May 31, 1971 a learned single Judge of the High Court allowed the revision application, granted the application filed by the respondent under section 17 D and directed the dismissal of the suit.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction between dismissal and modification/reversal unsound and opposed to Supreme Court precedents; merger applies even on dismissal after contested hearing

arguments.claim: Doctrine of merger applies such that decree of trial court merges in decree of High Court even upon dismissal of appeal after contested hearing; High Court decree dated January 8, 1969 is operative and executable

anchor.surface_text: principle of merger but a few preliminary observations will facilitate a better understanding of those decisions. The juristic justification of the doctrine of merger may be sought in the principle that there cannot be, at one and the same time. more than one operative order governing the same subject-matter.

arguments.claim: Section 17D empowers court to set aside only the operative and executable decree for possession; setting aside trial court decree while leaving appellate decrees outstanding would be empty exercise

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 D of the Act of 1956 confers power on the court to set aside decrees passed on account of the tenants default in the payment of rent. This power was conferred evidently in order to give further relief to defaulting tenants ... An effective and meaningful exercise of the power to set aside the decree for possession postulates a power to set aside an operative decree

arguments.claim: No merger of trial court decree in appellate court decree citing State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammad Nooh and State of Madras v. Madurai Mills as principle of merger has limited application
arguments.court_reasoning: Cases stand on special facts or different subject-matter; doctrine not rigidly applied where subject-matters differ but here identical

arguments.claim: Two questions raised: (1) trial court decree merged in High Court decree; (2) section 17D does not render eviction decree incapable of execution

arguments.claim: Merger applies per precedents like Jowad Hussain, CIT Amritlal Bhogilal, Collector of Customs East India Commercial even where appellate court merely affirms or dismisses appeal without modification

anchor.surface_text: In Jowad Hussain vs. Gendan Singh Ors., the, Privy Council while holding that the limitation of three years within which an application for a, final decree must be made runs fromthe date of the decree of the appellate court, quoted with approvalthe statement of law contained in the judgment of a learned judge of the Allahabad High Court

arguments.claim: Principle of merger distinguished in cases like Mohammad Nooh and Madurai Mills due to special facts or non-identical subject-matter; applies fully here as subject-matter identical and appeal on merits

holdings.text: the decree of the trial court dated November 24, 1958 merged in the decree of the High Court dated January 8, 1969

anchor.surface_text: We, are accordingly of the opinion that the decree of the trial companyrt dated November 24, 1958 merged in the decree of the High Court dated January 8, 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of merger applies as appeal was dismissed after contested hearing; appellate decree supersedes trial decree as operative and executable per precedents like Jowad Hussain, CIT Amritlal Bhogilal, Collector of Customs

holdings.text: Since the decree of the High Court was passed after the commencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Amendment Act 1968, that is to say after August 26, 1967, section 17D of the Act of 1956 can have no application

anchor.surface_text: Since the decree. of the High Court was passed after the companymencement of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy  Amendment  Act 1968, that is to say after August 26, 1967, section 17D of the Act of 1956 can have number application

holdings.reasoning_summary: Merged decree is High Court decree passed post-August 26, 1967 cutoff; s17D applies only to pre-commencement decrees under 1950 Act for rent default

holdings.text: the decree which section 17 D empowers the court to set aside is the decree which is capable of execution which, in this case, is the decree passed by the High Court on January 8, 1969

anchor.surface_text: The decree, therefore, which section 17 D empowers the companyrt to set aside is the decree which is capable of execution which, in this case, is the decree passed by the High Court on January 8, 1969.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of s17D requires setting aside only operative executable decree; post-merger, appellate decree is executable one

holdings.text: This distinction is unsound and is based on no discernible principle

anchor.surface_text: This companyclusion is clearly opposed the view taken by this Court in the decisions referred to above and the learned Judge was in error in making a distinction between an appellate judgment whereby an appeal is dismissed and an appellate judgment modifying or reversing the decree of the lower companyrt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in distinguishing dismissal from modification/reversal for merger; precedents confirm merger in all cases of appellate disposal after hearing

holdings.text: observations [in Mohammad Nooh and Madurai Mills] are evidently made in the context of the peculiar facts of the case and their application ought not to be extended beyond those facts
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished respondent precedents as limited to special facts/different subject-matters; merger fully applies where subject-matter identical and merits heard

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the judgment of the High Court dated May 31, 1971 and restore that of the Munsif, Second Court, Alipore dated July 15, 197
